body:
This looks like an interaction between go's name resolution code and systemd. Go doesn't use the libc interface it will query 127.0.0.53 as if it was a real nameserver.

What happens if you do `dig  www.googleapis.com @127.0.0.53` does that work?  Try several times and see if you  get the same result.

I'm wondering if this is a bug in `systemd-resolved` - maybe systemd/systemd#3981 ?

Hi,

Everything seem fine with dig :

$ dig www.googleapis.com @127.0.0.53

; <<>> DiG 9.10.4-P2 <<>> www.googleapis.com @127.0.0.53
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 43888
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 65494
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;www.googleapis.com.            IN      A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
www.googleapis.com.     3256    IN      CNAME   googleapis.l.google.com.

;; Query time: 0 msec
;; SERVER: 127.0.0.53#53(127.0.0.53)
;; WHEN: Tue Sep 06 08:28:32 CEST 2016
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 81

There was a fix to dns resolution in the latest go point release 1.7.1

https://github.com/golang/go/issues/16865

I'll compile a binary for you with it and you can see if that helps.

Try this beta and let me know what you think:

http://pub.rclone.org/v1.33-7-g54fdc68%CE%B2/

www.googleapis.com on 127.0.0.53:53: no such host

OK thanks for trying.

Is it easy for you to try older versions of systemd-resolved to see if any of them work with rclone?

No, sorryi can't try an old version of systemd-resolved because the
resolver is only related to the last version 231 (which i use). If i
downgrade systemd to version 230, there is no resolver service (and no open
port 53).

Christophe Yayon
cyayon@nbux.org

I see!

I'm inclined to think this is a bug in this very new feature of `systemd-resolved` then.

Can you report it to them too and see what they think?

Just noticed that there was a DNS resolver issue bug fixed in Go 1.7.1. Can  you try the latest beta which was compiled with Go 1.7.3 and see if that helps?

http://beta.rclone.org/v1.33-73-geca9e8e/

Is there an easy way for me to replicate this myself?  Maybe you could point me at a virtualbox image for the OS you are using, or give me instructions on how to build one?

Your `dig` output is *not* fine. It shows the CNAME record but not the corresponding A records. This is systemd/systemd#3826.

```console
$ dig +no{cmd,comments,stats} www.googleapis.com @8.8.8.8
;www.googleapis.com.		IN	A
www.googleapis.com.	3599	IN	CNAME	googleapis.l.google.com.
googleapis.l.google.com. 299	IN	A	216.58.219.202
googleapis.l.google.com. 299	IN	A	216.58.219.234
googleapis.l.google.com. 299	IN	A	172.217.0.42
googleapis.l.google.com. 299	IN	A	172.217.1.74
googleapis.l.google.com. 299	IN	A	172.217.4.42
googleapis.l.google.com. 299	IN	A	172.217.4.202
$ dig +no{cmd,comments,stats} www.googleapis.com @127.0.0.53
;www.googleapis.com.		IN	A
www.googleapis.com.	1740	IN	CNAME	googleapis.l.google.com.
$ ping www.googleapis.com
ping: www.googleapis.com: Name or service not known
```

Hi,

Thanks for your answer. It should be resolved in 232...
I will test.

Thanks.

--
Christophe Yayon

i am experiencing the same thing:

`2017/01/03 15:16:46 Failed to create file system for "m:": failed to make remote "acd:m" to wrap: failed to get endpoints: Get https://drive.amazonaws.com/drive/v1/account/endpoint: dial tcp: lookup drive.amazonaws.com on 127.0.0.53:53: no such host
`
rclone v1.35

One workaround is to install and enable dnsmasq (without dhcp support) and point `/etc/resolv.conf` to it.

Example `/etc/dnsmasq.conf` file:
```
listen-address=127.0.0.1
bind-interfaces
resolv-file=/run/systemd/resolve/resolv.conf
```

Example `/etc/resolv.conf` file:
```
nameserver 127.0.0.1
```

This way apps that use glibc and systemd APIs will still use systemd-resolved and apps that use `/etc/resolv.conf` directly (like rclone) will be directed to dnsmasq, which will receive up-to date list of nameservers from systemd-resolved.

The only missing feature would probably be the automatic restart of dnsmasq whenever `/run/systemd/resolve/resolv.conf` changes.

rindeal,

I tried that and i still get that error.
Can anyone please have solution for this. I am using latest beta 1.35.79

@motaro also make sure dnsmasq service starts after systemd-resolved by creating `/etc/systemd/system/dnsmasq.service.d/99-my.conf` file with content:

```ini
[Unit]
Requires=systemd-resolved.service
After=systemd-resolved.service
```

You may verify you set it up properly by running:

```
dig @127.0.0.1 google.com
dig @127.0.0.53 google.com
```

I cannot reproduce this issue using systemd 232 and 234. Both resolve the A records just fine and consequentially rclone also works. This was with Debian stable and testing, but I will also try with a fresh installation of arch.

@breunigs The patch for the systemd-resolved bug was already released for all affected versions of Debian and Ubuntu ([LP #1647031](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/systemd/+bug/1647031)). Also Debian doesn’t use systemd-resolved at all by default.

systemd 232 on the most recent arch iso (2017-07-01) is broken. Simply installing arch brings systemd to 233 already, where I cannot reproduce the bug anymore. I suggest everyone who experiences this bug to simply update their systems to a more recent systemd version (or at least one that has the patch backported, like the Debian/Ubuntu releases have).

@andersk The tests were done against systemd-resolved.
